page.title: 07Smarden - Local History
page.content: Smarden developed from a clearing in the Forest of Anderida and records show it was a parish in 1205, when Adam de Essex was rector. A copy of the charter of Elizabeth I endorsing that granted by Edward III in 1332 conferring the right to have a weekly market and an annual fair, hangs in the church. The Minnis which means 'land owned by the public' is the village playing field. A roofed pump in The Street commemorates the diamond jubilee of Queen Victoria in 1897. The entrance from The Street to the churchyard is under the Penthouse, the medieval term for an overhanging outhouse. Refugees from Europe, fleeing persecution, founded the cloth and wool trade upon which the village's prosperity was based. Linen was still being woven at Dragon House less than 100 years ago.
